body:
Edit: In hindsight I think I muddled my point by making this about news; I know that professional publications tend to be a lot less extreme than I've painted. I wrote this more with regards to my experience with 'social' sites that collate other articles and allow regular people to add their own comments / material - a source I look for to add context to a published article.

Not sure where on Ruqqus to post this, but it seems to fit the bill best here. Feel free to dump to +General otherwise.
TL;DR: Let's try to be better than football team politics.

--

Reddit used to be my go-to place for a neutral amalgamation of the week's news and public opinion, but with their increasingly bold-faced censorship and manipulation it's become clear that their neutrality (or at the very least equal representation of all biases) has now completely disappeared. In my search for truth I've taken to browsing different message boards / public platforms across the spectrum and trying to parse all of the bullshit for the common facts - but I'm finding more and more extremes of opinion to have to cut through. 

In left-leaning places we get:

- People demanding that the world validates and humours their every personal identity crisis or be punished
- Martyring of violent criminals who threatened police, declarations that "All Cops Are Bastards", and campaigning to exchange law and order for what is essentially vigilante justice
- Harassment, legal action and job losses for anyone who dares to have said or done something the mob doesn't like - past or present
- Demands for censorship of anything slightly uncomfortable (we should've seen it coming when 'trigger warnings' became a thing)
- Blind support for anything that sounds 'progressive' without any further investigation or scrutiny
- A bizarre trend of self-flagellation for historical events that modern people had no part in


Meanwhile on the right-leaning sites:

- A slurry of derogatory terms for every race, and lazy stereotyping
- Pushing overblown ultra-conservative nonsense just to 'trigger the libs', rather than from any personal convictions
- Childish memes where anything and anyone left of middle America gets mocked as screaming rainbow children against stoic, conservative 'real men' (Looking at you, PCM)
- Tinfoiling about ((the Jews)) at every opportunity
- Christian fundamentalists chomping at the bit for The Crusades II and going on puritanical rants about the evils of sexual liberation
- Lamenting the end of 'racial purity' as though nobody ever fucked outside their village before the 1950s (all of the white women you'll ever get to have sex with have already been born - calm down)


I don't particularly give a shit where the dot is on your political compass, but the ever-widening gap between the 'left' and 'right' is getting so silly I can't even search for the grains of truth between the extremes without rolling my eyes into the back of my head. Where the fuck are all of the normal people?

Is it just that the internet is populated with 13-to-25-year-olds who only deal in absolutes, or has everyone rushed to the far end of their respective spectrums? Is this shit doing anyone else's head in? If we really want to encourage some quality conversation we need to think beyond 'left' and 'right' and just take every issue on a case-by-case basis. It's intellectual tribalism; it's tiring, and it obfuscates the objective story.

body: I agree 100% with your statement. The ever loudening echo chambers are a major problem. Certain sites use algorithms to give you more of what you tend to want, sites like Facebook. And then we have people thinking that anything outside of their view is impossible because they are never exposed to it anymore. I am very happy with this site even though I must admit seeing some of the less savoury aspects of freedom of speech can be jarring. But I am committed to trying to make this site the dream site that reddit was in it's hay day. Challenge the crazies, engage in debate over the ideas and different ways of thinking. Maybe one day we get a good news source from right here.

In my search for truth I've taken to browsing different message boards / public platforms across the spectrum and trying to parse all of the bullshit for the common facts - but I'm finding more and more extremes of opinion to have to cut through.

In left-leaning places we get:

  • People demanding that the world validates and humours their every personal identity crisis or be punished
  • Martyring of violent criminals who threatened police, declarations that "All Cops Are Bastards", and campaigning to exchange law and order for what is essentially vigilante justice
  • Harassment, legal action and job losses for anyone who dares to have said or done something the mob doesn't like - past or present
  • Demands for censorship of anything slightly uncomfortable (we should've seen it coming when 'trigger warnings' became a thing)

  • A bizarre trend of self-flagellation for historical events that modern people had no part in

  • A slurry of derogatory terms for every race, and lazy stereotyping
  • Pushing overblown ultra-conservative nonsense just to 'trigger the libs', rather than from any personal convictions
  • Childish memes where anything and anyone left of middle America gets mocked as screaming rainbow children against stoic, conservative 'real men' (Looking at you, PCM)
  • Tinfoiling about ((the Jews)) at every opportunity

People are getting radicalised left right and center and it's extremely alarming that media outlets and echo chambers are actively encouraging it.

Even here in the UK the BBC who are supposed to be impartial have been trying to stir up outrage with ridiculous stories spun in a way to sound bad or annoy people.

A great recent example is they are giving platforms to people who have clearly either violated the law such as failing to stop for police but spinning it as a police brutality/racism angle. In reality police are getting scared to enforce the law half the time because it could cost them their job in the event of an out of context video.

  • People demanding that the world validates and humours their every personal identity crisis or be punished
  • Martyring of violent criminals who threatened police, declarations that "All Cops Are Bastards", and campaigning to exchange law and order for what is essentially vigilante justice
  • Harassment, legal action and job losses for anyone who dares to have said or done something the mob doesn't like - past or present
  • Demands for censorship of anything slightly uncomfortable (we should've seen it coming when 'trigger warnings' became a thing)
  • Blind support for anything that sounds 'progressive' without any further investigation or scrutiny
  • A bizarre trend of self-flagellation for historical events that modern people had no part in

  • A slurry of derogatory terms for every race, and lazy stereotyping
  • Pushing overblown ultra-conservative nonsense just to 'trigger the libs', rather than from any personal convictions
  • Childish memes where anything and anyone left of middle America gets mocked as screaming rainbow children against stoic, conservative 'real men' (Looking at you, PCM)

  • Lamenting the end of 'racial purity' as though nobody ever fucked outside their village before the 1950s (all of the white women you'll ever get to have sex with have already been born - calm down)

If you visit places like /pol/ or Kiwi Farms (though it's probably not fair to put KF in the same basket as they're pretty decent folk overall) you'll see plenty of it. Unfortunately at the same time these places do provide inconvenient insights and info that don't get much air on mainstream media. Their coverage of the whole BLM / CHAZ situation has been pretty thorough. 

In between that though is a cascade of commenters who would make my senile racist uncle say "that's a bit much, mate".

As I say, I've been trying to read from both sides of the fence, but everywhere 'community-based' is tending towards extremes and tribalism. Mainstream media has already been too corrupted by politics and careerism to take seriously for decades. All of this extra online noise is blinding.

In my search for truth I've taken to browsing different message boards / public platforms across the spectrum and trying to parse all of the bullshit for the common facts - but I'm finding more and more extremes of opinion to have to cut through.

In left-leaning places we get:

  • People demanding that the world validates and humours their every personal identity crisis or be punished
  • Martyring of violent criminals who threatened police, declarations that "All Cops Are Bastards", and campaigning to exchange law and order for what is essentially vigilante justice
  • Harassment, legal action and job losses for anyone who dares to have said or done something the mob doesn't like - past or present
  • Demands for censorship of anything slightly uncomfortable (we should've seen it coming when 'trigger warnings' became a thing)
  • Blind support for anything that sounds 'progressive' without any further investigation or scrutiny
  • A bizarre trend of self-flagellation for historical events that modern people had no part in

Meanwhile on the right-leaning sites:

  • A slurry of derogatory terms for every race, and lazy stereotyping
  • Pushing overblown ultra-conservative nonsense just to 'trigger the libs', rather than from any personal convictions
  • Childish memes where anything and anyone left of middle America gets mocked as screaming rainbow children against stoic, conservative 'real men' (Looking at you, PCM)
  • Tinfoiling about ((the Jews)) at every opportunity
  • Christian fundamentalists chomping at the bit for The Crusades II and going on puritanical rants about the evils of sexual liberation
  • Lamenting the end of 'racial purity' as though nobody ever fucked outside their village before the 1950s (all of the white women you'll ever get to have sex with have already been born - calm down)

I don't particularly give a shit where the dot is on your political compass, but the ever-widening gap between the 'left' and 'right' is getting so silly I can't even search for the grains of truth between the extremes without rolling my eyes into the back of my head. Where the fuck are all of the normal people?

Is it just that the internet is populated with 13-to-25-year-olds who only deal in absolutes, or has everyone rushed to the far end of their respective spectrums? Is this shit doing anyone else's head in? If we really want to encourage some quality conversation we need to think beyond 'left' and 'right' and just take every issue on a case-by-case basis. It's intellectual tribalism; it's tiring, and it obfuscates the objective story.

body:
Do you want to hear a positive in all of this? The bias in news sources is compelling people to think more critically on what they read and see. I think it's a good thing that I don't automatically trust what's in the local newspaper or what is being presented by the MSM anymore. Or even, something that I read on Twitter or any other social media. It reminds me of "Rashomon"; in that, you have to consider all sides IOT find the truth. Does it suck and take more time? YES, but you'll have a greater grasp on the issue at hand, too.

TL;DR: Let's try to be better than football team politics.

--

Reddit used to be my go-to place for a neutral amalgamation of the week's news and public opinion, but with their increasingly bold-faced censorship and manipulation it's become clear that their neutrality (or at the very least equal representation of all biases) has now completely disappeared. In my search for truth I've taken to browsing different message boards / public platforms across the spectrum and trying to parse all of the bullshit for the common facts - but I'm finding more and more extremes of opinion to have to cut through. 

In left-leaning places we get:

- People demanding that the world validates and humours their every personal identity crisis or be punished
- Martyring of violent criminals who threatened police, declarations that "All Cops Are Bastards", and campaigning to exchange law and order for what is essentially vigilante justice
- Harassment, legal action and job losses for anyone who dares to have said or done something the mob doesn't like - past or present
- Demands for censorship of anything slightly uncomfortable (we should've seen it coming when 'trigger warnings' became a thing)
- Blind support for anything that sounds 'progressive' without any further investigation or scrutiny
- A bizarre trend of self-flagellation for historical events that modern people had no part in


Meanwhile on the right-leaning sites:

- A slurry of derogatory terms for every race, and lazy stereotyping
- Pushing overblown ultra-conservative nonsense just to 'trigger the libs', rather than from any personal convictions
- Childish memes where anything and anyone left of middle America gets mocked as screaming rainbow children against stoic, conservative 'real men' (Looking at you, PCM)
- Tinfoiling about ((the Jews)) at every opportunity
- Christian fundamentalists chomping at the bit for The Crusades II and going on puritanical rants about the evils of sexual liberation
- Lamenting the end of 'racial purity' as though nobody ever fucked outside their village before the 1950s (all of the white women you'll ever get to have sex with have already been born - calm down)


I don't particularly give a shit where the dot is on your political compass, but the ever-widening gap between the 'left' and 'right' is getting so silly I can't even search for the grains of truth between the extremes without rolling my eyes into the back of my head. Where the fuck are all of the normal people?

Is it just that the internet is populated with 13-to-25-year-olds who only deal in absolutes, or has everyone rushed to the far end of their respective spectrums? Is this shit doing anyone else's head in? If we really want to encourage some quality conversation we need to think beyond 'left' and 'right' and just take every issue on a case-by-case basis. It's intellectual tribalism; it's tiring, and it obfuscates the objective story.

If you visit places like /pol/ or Kiwi Farms (though it's probably not fair to put KF in the same basket as they're pretty decent folk overall) you'll see plenty of it. Unfortunately at the same time these places do provide inconvenient insights and info that don't get much air on mainstream media. Their coverage of the whole BLM / CHAZ situation has been pretty thorough. 

In between that though is a cascade of commenters who would make my senile racist uncle say "that's a bit much, mate".

As I say, I've been trying to read from both sides of the fence, but everywhere 'community-based' is tending towards extremes and tribalism. Mainstream media has already been too corrupted by politics and careerism to take seriously for decades. All of this extra online noise is blinding.

Edit: In hindsight I think I muddled my point by making this about news; I know that professional publications tend to be a lot less extreme than I've painted. I wrote this more with regards to my experience with 'social' sites that collate other articles and allow regular people to add their own comments / material - a source I look for to add context to a published article.

Not sure where on Ruqqus to post this, but it seems to fit the bill best here. Feel free to dump to +General otherwise.
TL;DR: Let's try to be better than football team politics.

--

Reddit used to be my go-to place for a neutral amalgamation of the week's news and public opinion, but with their increasingly bold-faced censorship and manipulation it's become clear that their neutrality (or at the very least equal representation of all biases) has now completely disappeared. In my search for truth I've taken to browsing different message boards / public platforms across the spectrum and trying to parse all of the bullshit for the common facts - but I'm finding more and more extremes of opinion to have to cut through. 

In left-leaning places we get:

- People demanding that the world validates and humours their every personal identity crisis or be punished
- Martyring of violent criminals who threatened police, declarations that "All Cops Are Bastards", and campaigning to exchange law and order for what is essentially vigilante justice
- Harassment, legal action and job losses for anyone who dares to have said or done something the mob doesn't like - past or present
- Demands for censorship of anything slightly uncomfortable (we should've seen it coming when 'trigger warnings' became a thing)
- Blind support for anything that sounds 'progressive' without any further investigation or scrutiny
- A bizarre trend of self-flagellation for historical events that modern people had no part in


Meanwhile on the right-leaning sites:

- A slurry of derogatory terms for every race, and lazy stereotyping
- Pushing overblown ultra-conservative nonsense just to 'trigger the libs', rather than from any personal convictions
- Childish memes where anything and anyone left of middle America gets mocked as screaming rainbow children against stoic, conservative 'real men' (Looking at you, PCM)
- Tinfoiling about ((the Jews)) at every opportunity
- Christian fundamentalists chomping at the bit for The Crusades II and going on puritanical rants about the evils of sexual liberation
- Lamenting the end of 'racial purity' as though nobody ever fucked outside their village before the 1950s (all of the white women you'll ever get to have sex with have already been born - calm down)


I don't particularly give a shit where the dot is on your political compass, but the ever-widening gap between the 'left' and 'right' is getting so silly I can't even search for the grains of truth between the extremes without rolling my eyes into the back of my head. Where the fuck are all of the normal people?

Is it just that the internet is populated with 13-to-25-year-olds who only deal in absolutes, or has everyone rushed to the far end of their respective spectrums? Is this shit doing anyone else's head in? If we really want to encourage some quality conversation we need to think beyond 'left' and 'right' and just take every issue on a case-by-case basis. It's intellectual tribalism; it's tiring, and it obfuscates the objective story.

body:
Honestly the problem with the left-right dichotomy, at least in America, is the inability for compromise. 

Surely people can be convinced to support such fundamentally necessary things as universal healthcare, funding for education, and trade agreements, but the politicians on each side wants THEIR party to be the one to solve the issue. 

It happens on both sides, but recent history has shown that it was the Republicans are the ones who begun acting like they were always in the majority, and would block all democratic legislation. This is mostly the fault of Mitch McConnell. 

Worse, years of attempting to act like "the better party" have failed to work for the democrats, who cant get any compromise on anything but the most nonpartisan or hotly demanded issues. So now they do the same shit. Recently, Democrats have blocked Trump from pulling troops from Afghanistan, even though WE ALL WANT TO LEAVE AFGHANISTAN!! They just don't want him to get the credit for it. 

The big problem is our voting system. First past the post is trash. We need a ranked voting system, to let other parties have representation. The Dems+Repubs will happily work to keep FPP in place, because they know it's what keeps them in power.

Really though, they're two wings of the same dumb bird. They're funded by the same people, they're both fundamentally pro-business, they just gripe about whatever particular special issues they can to get their base riled up. ie abortion, gun laws, immigration, etc.

Our political system is scuffed and broken

Edit: In hindsight I think I muddled my point by making this about news; I know that professional publications tend to be a lot less extreme than I've painted. I wrote this more with regards to my experience with 'social' sites that collate other articles and allow regular people to add their own comments / material - a source I look for to add context to a published article.

Not sure where on Ruqqus to post this, but it seems to fit the bill best here. Feel free to dump to +General otherwise.
TL;DR: Let's try to be better than football team politics.

--

Reddit used to be my go-to place for a neutral amalgamation of the week's news and public opinion, but with their increasingly bold-faced censorship and manipulation it's become clear that their neutrality (or at the very least equal representation of all biases) has now completely disappeared. In my search for truth I've taken to browsing different message boards / public platforms across the spectrum and trying to parse all of the bullshit for the common facts - but I'm finding more and more extremes of opinion to have to cut through. 

In left-leaning places we get:

- People demanding that the world validates and humours their every personal identity crisis or be punished
- Martyring of violent criminals who threatened police, declarations that "All Cops Are Bastards", and campaigning to exchange law and order for what is essentially vigilante justice
- Harassment, legal action and job losses for anyone who dares to have said or done something the mob doesn't like - past or present
- Demands for censorship of anything slightly uncomfortable (we should've seen it coming when 'trigger warnings' became a thing)
- Blind support for anything that sounds 'progressive' without any further investigation or scrutiny
- A bizarre trend of self-flagellation for historical events that modern people had no part in


Meanwhile on the right-leaning sites:

- A slurry of derogatory terms for every race, and lazy stereotyping
- Pushing overblown ultra-conservative nonsense just to 'trigger the libs', rather than from any personal convictions
- Childish memes where anything and anyone left of middle America gets mocked as screaming rainbow children against stoic, conservative 'real men' (Looking at you, PCM)
- Tinfoiling about ((the Jews)) at every opportunity
- Christian fundamentalists chomping at the bit for The Crusades II and going on puritanical rants about the evils of sexual liberation
- Lamenting the end of 'racial purity' as though nobody ever fucked outside their village before the 1950s (all of the white women you'll ever get to have sex with have already been born - calm down)


I don't particularly give a shit where the dot is on your political compass, but the ever-widening gap between the 'left' and 'right' is getting so silly I can't even search for the grains of truth between the extremes without rolling my eyes into the back of my head. Where the fuck are all of the normal people?

Is it just that the internet is populated with 13-to-25-year-olds who only deal in absolutes, or has everyone rushed to the far end of their respective spectrums? Is this shit doing anyone else's head in? If we really want to encourage some quality conversation we need to think beyond 'left' and 'right' and just take every issue on a case-by-case basis. It's intellectual tribalism; it's tiring, and it obfuscates the objective story.

post.body:
Edit: In hindsight I think I muddled my point by making this about news; I know that professional publications tend to be a lot less extreme than I've painted. I wrote this more with regards to my experience with 'social' sites that collate other articles and allow regular people to add their own comments / material - a source I look for to add context to a published article.

Not sure where on Ruqqus to post this, but it seems to fit the bill best here. Feel free to dump to +General otherwise.
TL;DR: Let's try to be better than football team politics.

--

Reddit used to be my go-to place for a neutral amalgamation of the week's news and public opinion, but with their increasingly bold-faced censorship and manipulation it's become clear that their neutrality (or at the very least equal representation of all biases) has now completely disappeared. In my search for truth I've taken to browsing different message boards / public platforms across the spectrum and trying to parse all of the bullshit for the common facts - but I'm finding more and more extremes of opinion to have to cut through. 

In left-leaning places we get:

- People demanding that the world validates and humours their every personal identity crisis or be punished
- Martyring of violent criminals who threatened police, declarations that "All Cops Are Bastards", and campaigning to exchange law and order for what is essentially vigilante justice
- Harassment, legal action and job losses for anyone who dares to have said or done something the mob doesn't like - past or present
- Demands for censorship of anything slightly uncomfortable (we should've seen it coming when 'trigger warnings' became a thing)
- Blind support for anything that sounds 'progressive' without any further investigation or scrutiny
- A bizarre trend of self-flagellation for historical events that modern people had no part in


Meanwhile on the right-leaning sites:

- A slurry of derogatory terms for every race, and lazy stereotyping
- Pushing overblown ultra-conservative nonsense just to 'trigger the libs', rather than from any personal convictions
- Childish memes where anything and anyone left of middle America gets mocked as screaming rainbow children against stoic, conservative 'real men' (Looking at you, PCM)
- Tinfoiling about ((the Jews)) at every opportunity
- Christian fundamentalists chomping at the bit for The Crusades II and going on puritanical rants about the evils of sexual liberation
- Lamenting the end of 'racial purity' as though nobody ever fucked outside their village before the 1950s (all of the white women you'll ever get to have sex with have already been born - calm down)


I don't particularly give a shit where the dot is on your political compass, but the ever-widening gap between the 'left' and 'right' is getting so silly I can't even search for the grains of truth between the extremes without rolling my eyes into the back of my head. Where the fuck are all of the normal people?

Is it just that the internet is populated with 13-to-25-year-olds who only deal in absolutes, or has everyone rushed to the far end of their respective spectrums? Is this shit doing anyone else's head in? If we really want to encourage some quality conversation we need to think beyond 'left' and 'right' and just take every issue on a case-by-case basis. It's intellectual tribalism; it's tiring, and it obfuscates the objective story.

parent.body: I agree 100% with your statement. The ever loudening echo chambers are a major problem. Certain sites use algorithms to give you more of what you tend to want, sites like Facebook. And then we have people thinking that anything outside of their view is impossible because they are never exposed to it anymore. I am very happy with this site even though I must admit seeing some of the less savoury aspects of freedom of speech can be jarring. But I am committed to trying to make this site the dream site that reddit was in it's hay day. Challenge the crazies, engage in debate over the ideas and different ways of thinking. Maybe one day we get a good news source from right here.

body:
I think the news media itself is to blame for most of this. Is it just a money thing though, with clickbait and hate selling? Or is there something else at play, with the media outlets being controlled by certain groups, whether political or otherwise, who aim to divide and stir up hate, push narratives and brainwash the public with misinfo? Shit, almost every news headline on reddit is completely misleading nowadays and the vast majority of users consistently state complete falsehoods as if fact. reddit is by far the worst offender nowadays but it's become the norm.

We all know the media has been doing the same thing forever, it's been propaganda forever, but why has it suddenly turned it up to 11 leading to this craziness? Is it in response to Trump winning the Presidency and threatening the status quo? Something else?

Is it the internet being controlled and taking over by these same media outlets and political groups, like they've finally figured out how it works and the internet culture, websites like reddit etc.. and that's allowing the shit to be thrust in everyone's face 24/7 making it much more amplified than when it was just on TV and in print?

IMO the only way out of it is by getting away from mainstream media, controlled sites etc. but nowadays they're almost all taken over, and the big players have a monopoly. What can you do? Maybe it's just a case of making people aware that this shit is not healthy and aware that it's the media and control of sites like reddit which are the real danger, not some orange bloke in the WH or white people, or black people and immigrants etc. There needs to be an uprising and protests, but against those fuckers IMO, because they are destroying society far quicker than any of the aforementioned groups could.

Why do we get the joy of choosing between a giant douche and a turd sandwich nearly every election cycle?  FPP.

Why are there only two real political parties in the US, ensuring that you probably can't vote for representation that matches your personal views very well?  You guessed it -- FPP.

Why do we have gerrymandering and the voter disenfranchisement that goes along with the eternal quest to create 'safe seats' for the dominant parties?  Yep, FPP again.

There are many more problems with FPP, but these are more than enough to replace it with something more sensible.

parent.body:
Honestly the problem with the left-right dichotomy, at least in America, is the inability for compromise. 

Surely people can be convinced to support such fundamentally necessary things as universal healthcare, funding for education, and trade agreements, but the politicians on each side wants THEIR party to be the one to solve the issue. 

It happens on both sides, but recent history has shown that it was the Republicans are the ones who begun acting like they were always in the majority, and would block all democratic legislation. This is mostly the fault of Mitch McConnell. 

Worse, years of attempting to act like "the better party" have failed to work for the democrats, who cant get any compromise on anything but the most nonpartisan or hotly demanded issues. So now they do the same shit. Recently, Democrats have blocked Trump from pulling troops from Afghanistan, even though WE ALL WANT TO LEAVE AFGHANISTAN!! They just don't want him to get the credit for it. 

The big problem is our voting system. First past the post is trash. We need a ranked voting system, to let other parties have representation. The Dems+Repubs will happily work to keep FPP in place, because they know it's what keeps them in power.

Really though, they're two wings of the same dumb bird. They're funded by the same people, they're both fundamentally pro-business, they just gripe about whatever particular special issues they can to get their base riled up. ie abortion, gun laws, immigration, etc.

Our political system is scuffed and broken

parent.body:
I have mixed feelings about much of the parent post, but this part:

> The big problem is our voting system. First past the post is trash. We need a ranked voting system, to let other parties have representation. The Dems+Repubs will happily work to keep FPP in place, because they know it's what keeps them in power.

Is so very true and cannot be emphasized strongly enough.  First past the post is the root of so many of the political problems in the US.

Why do we get the joy of choosing between a giant douche and a turd sandwich nearly every election cycle?  FPP.

Why are there only two real political parties in the US, ensuring that you probably can't vote for representation that matches your personal views very well?  You guessed it -- FPP.

Why do we have gerrymandering and the voter disenfranchisement that goes along with the eternal quest to create 'safe seats' for the dominant parties?  Yep, FPP again.

There are many more problems with FPP, but these are more than enough to replace it with something more sensible.

As a side note, you get objectivity by taking in both sides arguments and forming your own conclusions. This is nothing new.

Posts like this are why I really like Ruqqus so far. It's certainly something worth fighting to keep exactly as is.

body:
Certainly.  First off, I +1'd your post and responded because I thought it was thoughtfully written.

> Surely people can be convinced to support such fundamentally necessary things as universal healthcare, funding for education,

I assumed here that you meant 100% state supported healthcare and education funding.  I don't see that as positive for a society, although I do believe quality education and healthcare should be more accessible than they currently are.  Like I said, mixed feelings.

> It happens on both sides, but recent history has shown that it was the Republicans are the ones who begun acting like they were always in the majority, and would block all democratic legislation. This is mostly the fault of Mitch McConnell.
> Worse, years of attempting to act like "the better party" have failed to work for the democrats, who cant get any compromise on anything but the most nonpartisan or hotly demanded issues. So now they do the same shit

I think you're being too kind to the democrats here.  Both parties are (and always have been) ruthless in their political machinations.

The issue is that we need to change the parts of the system that incentivize politicians to work counter to interests of the governed.  You highlighted first past the post as one of those parts, and I couldn't agree more.

> they're both fundamentally pro-business

I think they're both fundamentally pro establishment, but there are important differences around business policy

post.body:
Edit: In hindsight I think I muddled my point by making this about news; I know that professional publications tend to be a lot less extreme than I've painted. I wrote this more with regards to my experience with 'social' sites that collate other articles and allow regular people to add their own comments / material - a source I look for to add context to a published article.

Not sure where on Ruqqus to post this, but it seems to fit the bill best here. Feel free to dump to +General otherwise.
TL;DR: Let's try to be better than football team politics.

--

Reddit used to be my go-to place for a neutral amalgamation of the week's news and public opinion, but with their increasingly bold-faced censorship and manipulation it's become clear that their neutrality (or at the very least equal representation of all biases) has now completely disappeared. In my search for truth I've taken to browsing different message boards / public platforms across the spectrum and trying to parse all of the bullshit for the common facts - but I'm finding more and more extremes of opinion to have to cut through. 

In left-leaning places we get:

- People demanding that the world validates and humours their every personal identity crisis or be punished
- Martyring of violent criminals who threatened police, declarations that "All Cops Are Bastards", and campaigning to exchange law and order for what is essentially vigilante justice
- Harassment, legal action and job losses for anyone who dares to have said or done something the mob doesn't like - past or present
- Demands for censorship of anything slightly uncomfortable (we should've seen it coming when 'trigger warnings' became a thing)
- Blind support for anything that sounds 'progressive' without any further investigation or scrutiny
- A bizarre trend of self-flagellation for historical events that modern people had no part in


Meanwhile on the right-leaning sites:

- A slurry of derogatory terms for every race, and lazy stereotyping
- Pushing overblown ultra-conservative nonsense just to 'trigger the libs', rather than from any personal convictions
- Childish memes where anything and anyone left of middle America gets mocked as screaming rainbow children against stoic, conservative 'real men' (Looking at you, PCM)
- Tinfoiling about ((the Jews)) at every opportunity
- Christian fundamentalists chomping at the bit for The Crusades II and going on puritanical rants about the evils of sexual liberation
- Lamenting the end of 'racial purity' as though nobody ever fucked outside their village before the 1950s (all of the white women you'll ever get to have sex with have already been born - calm down)


I don't particularly give a shit where the dot is on your political compass, but the ever-widening gap between the 'left' and 'right' is getting so silly I can't even search for the grains of truth between the extremes without rolling my eyes into the back of my head. Where the fuck are all of the normal people?

Is it just that the internet is populated with 13-to-25-year-olds who only deal in absolutes, or has everyone rushed to the far end of their respective spectrums? Is this shit doing anyone else's head in? If we really want to encourage some quality conversation we need to think beyond 'left' and 'right' and just take every issue on a case-by-case basis. It's intellectual tribalism; it's tiring, and it obfuscates the objective story.

body: There really doesn't seem to be a clean solution to the problem of media bias. You could reintroduce legal standards of objectivity, but you run the risk of government capture of the media. Personally, I wish there was a news organization owned by the journalists who operated it. They wouldn't be beholden to corporate overlords on either side. That still has problems too though because the journalists can have personal bias. After all, the radical shift in the New York Times seems to be the result of an internal push by younger more leftist journalists.

author.bio: Literally Hitler.

body:
Many feel the same way you do, but are too silent to say so. You can try challenging your friends in somewhat of a non-combative way. It's really tough to break past the brainwashing of critical theory and the like. It seems that enlightenment is dead.

If you've come to a logical and sound conclusion then be a man and stand by it. Don't allow others to enforce thought crime on you and don't let others approval dictate your life. *Allow* yourself to be challenged and engage in open honest discussion. If they're unwilling to listen or challenge your ideas with sound logic, maybe you're wasting your time. Not to say that you need to ostracize your friends, but if it's bothering you this much try to find new friends. 

I went through something very similar. Tried for honest conversation and defending my point of view. Some are no longer friends, some ended up agreeing, some still disagree yet are far more reasonable and engage in conversation.

It's the blessing and curse of critical thinking. Some are happy blindly following the herd and don't like to think for themselves (look at how quickly the NPC meme was banned). People used to grow out of this sort of childish thinking. You'd be surprised how many people grow out of this thinking when they get a real job, house, kids, etc.

Whatever you do don't give up. Hold your head high, make yourself successful in body and mind, and be the change you want to see. Silence is the death of ideas.

You are not alone.

In my search for truth I've taken to browsing different message boards / public platforms across the spectrum and trying to parse all of the bullshit for the common facts - but I'm finding more and more extremes of opinion to have to cut through. 

In left-leaning places we get:

- People demanding that the world validates and humours their every personal identity crisis or be punished
- Martyring of violent criminals who threatened police, declarations that "All Cops Are Bastards", and campaigning to exchange law and order for what is essentially vigilante justice
- Harassment, legal action and job losses for anyone who dares to have said or done something the mob doesn't like - past or present
- Demands for censorship of anything slightly uncomfortable (we should've seen it coming when 'trigger warnings' became a thing)
- Blind support for anything that sounds 'progressive' without any further investigation or scrutiny
- A bizarre trend of self-flagellation for historical events that modern people had no part in


Meanwhile on the right-leaning sites:

- A slurry of derogatory terms for every race, and lazy stereotyping
- Pushing overblown ultra-conservative nonsense just to 'trigger the libs', rather than from any personal convictions
- Childish memes where anything and anyone left of middle America gets mocked as screaming rainbow children against stoic, conservative 'real men' (Looking at you, PCM)
- Tinfoiling about ((the Jews)) at every opportunity
- Christian fundamentalists chomping at the bit for The Crusades II and going on puritanical rants about the evils of sexual liberation
- Lamenting the end of 'racial purity' as though nobody ever fucked outside their village before the 1950s (all of the white women you'll ever get to have sex with have already been born - calm down)


I don't particularly give a shit where the dot is on your political compass, but the ever-widening gap between the 'left' and 'right' is getting so silly I can't even search for the grains of truth between the extremes without rolling my eyes into the back of my head. Is it just that the internet is populated with 13-to-25-year-olds who only deal in absolutes, or has everyone rushed to the far end of their respective spectrums? Is this shit doing anyone else's head in? If we really want to encourage some quality conversation we need to think beyond 'left' and 'right' and just take every issue on a case-by-case basis. It's intellectual tribalism; it's tiring, and it obfuscates the objective story.

> Surely people can be convinced to support such fundamentally necessary things as universal healthcare, funding for education,

I assumed here that you meant 100% state supported healthcare and education funding.  I don't see that as positive for a society, although I do believe quality education and healthcare should be more accessible than they currently are.  Like I said, mixed feelings.

> It happens on both sides, but recent history has shown that it was the Republicans are the ones who begun acting like they were always in the majority, and would block all democratic legislation. This is mostly the fault of Mitch McConnell.
> Worse, years of attempting to act like "the better party" have failed to work for the democrats, who cant get any compromise on anything but the most nonpartisan or hotly demanded issues. So now they do the same shit

I think you're being too kind to the democrats here.  Both parties are (and always have been) ruthless in their political machinations.

The issue is that we need to change the parts of the system that incentivize politicians to work counter to interests of the governed.  You highlighted first past the post as one of those parts, and I couldn't agree more.

> they're both fundamentally pro-business

I think they're both fundamentally pro establishment, but there are important differences around business policy

Reddit used to be my go-to place for a neutral amalgamation of the week's news and public opinion, but with their increasingly bold-faced censorship and manipulation it's become clear that their neutrality (or at the very least equal representation of all biases) has now completely disappeared. In my search for truth I've taken to browsing different message boards / public platforms across the spectrum and trying to parse all of the bullshit for the common facts - but I'm finding more and more extremes of opinion to have to cut through. 

In left-leaning places we get:

- People demanding that the world validates and humours their every personal identity crisis or be punished
- Martyring of violent criminals who threatened police, declarations that "All Cops Are Bastards", and campaigning to exchange law and order for what is essentially vigilante justice
- Harassment, legal action and job losses for anyone who dares to have said or done something the mob doesn't like - past or present
- Demands for censorship of anything slightly uncomfortable (we should've seen it coming when 'trigger warnings' became a thing)
- Blind support for anything that sounds 'progressive' without any further investigation or scrutiny
- A bizarre trend of self-flagellation for historical events that modern people had no part in


Meanwhile on the right-leaning sites:

- A slurry of derogatory terms for every race, and lazy stereotyping
- Pushing overblown ultra-conservative nonsense just to 'trigger the libs', rather than from any personal convictions
- Childish memes where anything and anyone left of middle America gets mocked as screaming rainbow children against stoic, conservative 'real men' (Looking at you, PCM)
- Tinfoiling about ((the Jews)) at every opportunity
- Christian fundamentalists chomping at the bit for The Crusades II and going on puritanical rants about the evils of sexual liberation
- Lamenting the end of 'racial purity' as though nobody ever fucked outside their village before the 1950s (all of the white women you'll ever get to have sex with have already been born - calm down)


I don't particularly give a shit where the dot is on your political compass, but the ever-widening gap between the 'left' and 'right' is getting so silly I can't even search for the grains of truth between the extremes without rolling my eyes into the back of my head. Where the fuck are all of the normal people?

Is it just that the internet is populated with 13-to-25-year-olds who only deal in absolutes, or has everyone rushed to the far end of their respective spectrums? Is this shit doing anyone else's head in? If we really want to encourage some quality conversation we need to think beyond 'left' and 'right' and just take every issue on a case-by-case basis. It's intellectual tribalism; it's tiring, and it obfuscates the objective story.

In my search for truth I've taken to browsing different message boards / public platforms across the spectrum and trying to parse all of the bullshit for the common facts - but I'm finding more and more extremes of opinion to have to cut through. 

In left-leaning places we get:

- People demanding that the world validates and humours their every personal identity crisis or be punished
- Martyring of violent criminals who threatened police, declarations that "All Cops Are Bastards", and campaigning to exchange law and order for what is essentially vigilante justice
- Harassment, legal action and job losses for anyone who dares to have said or done something the mob doesn't like - past or present
- Demands for censorship of anything slightly uncomfortable (we should've seen it coming when 'trigger warnings' became a thing)
- Blind support for anything that sounds 'progressive' without any further investigation or scrutiny
- A bizarre trend of self-flagellation for historical events that modern people had no part in


Meanwhile on the right-leaning sites:

- A slurry of derogatory terms for every race, and lazy stereotyping
- Pushing overblown ultra-conservative nonsense just to 'trigger the libs', rather than from any personal convictions
- Childish memes where anything and anyone left of middle America gets mocked as screaming rainbow children against stoic, conservative 'real men' (Looking at you, PCM)
- Tinfoiling about ((the Jews)) at every opportunity
- Christian fundamentalists chomping at the bit for The Crusades II and going on puritanical rants about the evils of sexual liberation
- Lamenting the end of 'racial purity' as though nobody ever fucked outside their village before the 1950s (all of the white women you'll ever get to have sex with have already been born - calm down)


I don't particularly give a shit where the dot is on your political compass, but the ever-widening gap between the 'left' and 'right' is getting so silly I can't even search for the grains of truth between the extremes without rolling my eyes into the back of my head. Where the fuck are all of the normal people?

Is it just that the internet is populated with 13-to-25-year-olds who only deal in absolutes, or has everyone rushed to the far end of their respective spectrums? Is this shit doing anyone else's head in? If we really want to encourage some quality conversation we need to think beyond 'left' and 'right' and just take every issue on a case-by-case basis. It's intellectual tribalism; it's tiring, and it obfuscates the objective story.

body:
Objective news is a myth. Journalists are people and ALL people are biased. Some hide it better than others, but people simply cannot cover every single topic from all perspectives due to time and resource constraints. 

It is better to read both sides. For example, I am a conservative and will vote for Trump but I know that Trump is not a good person thanks to reading the liberal media. I would never give Trump a business loan and I wouldn't be surprised if Trump stabbed me in the back if I ever worked for him. But because I also read conservative media, I know Trump is a lot more sane than Democrats and supports much more logical policies concerning immigration, law enforcement, etc. than the left.

Reddit used to be my go-to place for a neutral amalgamation of the week's news and public opinion, but with their increasingly bold-faced censorship and manipulation it's become clear that their neutrality (or at the very least equal representation of all biases) has now completely disappeared. In my search for truth I've taken to browsing different message boards / public platforms across the spectrum and trying to parse all of the bullshit for the common facts - but I'm finding more and more extremes of opinion to have to cut through. 

In left-leaning places we get:

- People demanding that the world validates and humours their every personal identity crisis or be punished
- Martyring of violent criminals who threatened police, declarations that "All Cops Are Bastards", and campaigning to exchange law and order for what is essentially vigilante justice
- Harassment, legal action and job losses for anyone who dares to have said or done something the mob doesn't like - past or present
- Demands for censorship of anything slightly uncomfortable (we should've seen it coming when 'trigger warnings' became a thing)
- Blind support for anything that sounds 'progressive' without any further investigation or scrutiny
- A bizarre trend of self-flagellation for historical events that modern people had no part in


Meanwhile on the right-leaning sites:

- A slurry of derogatory terms for every race, and lazy stereotyping
- Pushing overblown ultra-conservative nonsense just to 'trigger the libs', rather than from any personal convictions
- Childish memes where anything and anyone left of middle America gets mocked as screaming rainbow children against stoic, conservative 'real men' (Looking at you, PCM)
- Tinfoiling about ((the Jews)) at every opportunity
- Christian fundamentalists chomping at the bit for The Crusades II and going on puritanical rants about the evils of sexual liberation
- Lamenting the end of 'racial purity' as though nobody ever fucked outside their village before the 1950s (all of the white women you'll ever get to have sex with have already been born - calm down)


I don't particularly give a shit where the dot is on your political compass, but the ever-widening gap between the 'left' and 'right' is getting so silly I can't even search for the grains of truth between the extremes without rolling my eyes into the back of my head. Where the fuck are all of the normal people?

Is it just that the internet is populated with 13-to-25-year-olds who only deal in absolutes, or has everyone rushed to the far end of their respective spectrums? Is this shit doing anyone else's head in? If we really want to encourage some quality conversation we need to think beyond 'left' and 'right' and just take every issue on a case-by-case basis. It's intellectual tribalism; it's tiring, and it obfuscates the objective story.

Edit: In hindsight I think I muddled my point by making this about news; I know that professional publications tend to be a lot less extreme than I've painted. I wrote this more with regards to my experience with 'social' sites that collate other articles and allow regular people to add their own comments / material - a source I look for to add context to a published article.

Not sure where on Ruqqus to post this, but it seems to fit the bill best here. Feel free to dump to +General otherwise.
TL;DR: Let's try to be better than football team politics.

--

Reddit used to be my go-to place for a neutral amalgamation of the week's news and public opinion, but with their increasingly bold-faced censorship and manipulation it's become clear that their neutrality (or at the very least equal representation of all biases) has now completely disappeared. In my search for truth I've taken to browsing different message boards / public platforms across the spectrum and trying to parse all of the bullshit for the common facts - but I'm finding more and more extremes of opinion to have to cut through. 

In left-leaning places we get:

- People demanding that the world validates and humours their every personal identity crisis or be punished
- Martyring of violent criminals who threatened police, declarations that "All Cops Are Bastards", and campaigning to exchange law and order for what is essentially vigilante justice
- Harassment, legal action and job losses for anyone who dares to have said or done something the mob doesn't like - past or present
- Demands for censorship of anything slightly uncomfortable (we should've seen it coming when 'trigger warnings' became a thing)
- Blind support for anything that sounds 'progressive' without any further investigation or scrutiny
- A bizarre trend of self-flagellation for historical events that modern people had no part in


Meanwhile on the right-leaning sites:

- A slurry of derogatory terms for every race, and lazy stereotyping
- Pushing overblown ultra-conservative nonsense just to 'trigger the libs', rather than from any personal convictions
- Childish memes where anything and anyone left of middle America gets mocked as screaming rainbow children against stoic, conservative 'real men' (Looking at you, PCM)
- Tinfoiling about ((the Jews)) at every opportunity
- Christian fundamentalists chomping at the bit for The Crusades II and going on puritanical rants about the evils of sexual liberation
- Lamenting the end of 'racial purity' as though nobody ever fucked outside their village before the 1950s (all of the white women you'll ever get to have sex with have already been born - calm down)


I don't particularly give a shit where the dot is on your political compass, but the ever-widening gap between the 'left' and 'right' is getting so silly I can't even search for the grains of truth between the extremes without rolling my eyes into the back of my head. Where the fuck are all of the normal people?

Is it just that the internet is populated with 13-to-25-year-olds who only deal in absolutes, or has everyone rushed to the far end of their respective spectrums? Is this shit doing anyone else's head in? If we really want to encourage some quality conversation we need to think beyond 'left' and 'right' and just take every issue on a case-by-case basis. It's intellectual tribalism; it's tiring, and it obfuscates the objective story.

body:
Read a book called 'True Believer: Thoughts on the Nature of Mass Movements' by Eric Hoffer, published in 1951. It's out of print, but you can get used copies. I think it should be required reading. It's not a scientific work, but it is very astute, and describes a lot of what we're seeing. He talks about the types people who are predisposed to fanaticism, and how if one is a fanatic the specific cause almost doesn't matter. They will find something to fight for. Sort of how half the BLM rioters at the moment are libLeft white women, and have the full backing of every major institution in the country. Zealotry is it seems part of human nature in a not insignificant portion of the population. 

The Internet in general, and social media specifically has been instrumental in organizing people into mass movements. Some of it is organic and self-organizing, like tiger sanctuary zealots, peta, and antivaxxers. Some of it is engineered, e.g. the various color revolutions we have seen over the past decade. I'd say a lot are coopted all, or in part like identity politics has become. It's likely only going to get worse.  

https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/17715-the-true-believer-thoughts-on-the-nature-of-mass-movements

parent.body:
I have mixed feelings about much of the parent post, but this part:

> The big problem is our voting system. First past the post is trash. We need a ranked voting system, to let other parties have representation. The Dems+Repubs will happily work to keep FPP in place, because they know it's what keeps them in power.

Is so very true and cannot be emphasized strongly enough.  First past the post is the root of so many of the political problems in the US.

Why do we get the joy of choosing between a giant douche and a turd sandwich nearly every election cycle?  FPP.

Why are there only two real political parties in the US, ensuring that you probably can't vote for representation that matches your personal views very well?  You guessed it -- FPP.

Why do we have gerrymandering and the voter disenfranchisement that goes along with the eternal quest to create 'safe seats' for the dominant parties?  Yep, FPP again.

There are many more problems with FPP, but these are more than enough to replace it with something more sensible.

parent.body:
Read a book called 'True Believer: Thoughts on the Nature of Mass Movements' by Eric Hoffer, published in 1951. It's out of print, but you can get used copies. I think it should be required reading. It's not a scientific work, but it is very astute, and describes a lot of what we're seeing. He talks about the types people who are predisposed to fanaticism, and how if one is a fanatic the specific cause almost doesn't matter. They will find something to fight for. Sort of how half the BLM rioters at the moment are libLeft white women, and have the full backing of every major institution in the country. Zealotry is it seems part of human nature in a not insignificant portion of the population. 

The Internet in general, and social media specifically has been instrumental in organizing people into mass movements. Some of it is organic and self-organizing, like tiger sanctuary zealots, peta, and antivaxxers. Some of it is engineered, e.g. the various color revolutions we have seen over the past decade. I'd say a lot are coopted all, or in part like identity politics has become. It's likely only going to get worse.  

https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/17715-the-true-believer-thoughts-on-the-nature-of-mass-movements

Reddit used to be my go-to place for a neutral amalgamation of the week's news and public opinion, but with their increasingly bold-faced censorship and manipulation it's become clear that their neutrality (or at the very least equal representation of all biases) has now completely disappeared. In my search for truth I've taken to browsing different message boards / public platforms across the spectrum and trying to parse all of the bullshit for the common facts - but I'm finding more and more extremes of opinion to have to cut through. 

In left-leaning places we get:

- People demanding that the world validates and humours their every personal identity crisis or be punished
- Martyring of violent criminals who threatened police, declarations that "All Cops Are Bastards", and campaigning to exchange law and order for what is essentially vigilante justice
- Harassment, legal action and job losses for anyone who dares to have said or done something the mob doesn't like - past or present
- Demands for censorship of anything slightly uncomfortable (we should've seen it coming when 'trigger warnings' became a thing)
- Blind support for anything that sounds 'progressive' without any further investigation or scrutiny
- A bizarre trend of self-flagellation for historical events that modern people had no part in


Meanwhile on the right-leaning sites:

- A slurry of derogatory terms for every race, and lazy stereotyping
- Pushing overblown ultra-conservative nonsense just to 'trigger the libs', rather than from any personal convictions
- Childish memes where anything and anyone left of middle America gets mocked as screaming rainbow children against stoic, conservative 'real men' (Looking at you, PCM)
- Tinfoiling about ((the Jews)) at every opportunity
- Christian fundamentalists chomping at the bit for The Crusades II and going on puritanical rants about the evils of sexual liberation
- Lamenting the end of 'racial purity' as though nobody ever fucked outside their village before the 1950s (all of the white women you'll ever get to have sex with have already been born - calm down)


I don't particularly give a shit where the dot is on your political compass, but the ever-widening gap between the 'left' and 'right' is getting so silly I can't even search for the grains of truth between the extremes without rolling my eyes into the back of my head. Where the fuck are all of the normal people?

Is it just that the internet is populated with 13-to-25-year-olds who only deal in absolutes, or has everyone rushed to the far end of their respective spectrums? Is this shit doing anyone else's head in? If we really want to encourage some quality conversation we need to think beyond 'left' and 'right' and just take every issue on a case-by-case basis. It's intellectual tribalism; it's tiring, and it obfuscates the objective story.
